text: I think it will remain the same it my
voice does not depend on my age but it
depends on the work that I do and they
campaign that I do so being here with
the children in Lebanon with the Syrian
refugees
it makes my voice more powerful because
it's not just my voice it's the voice of
all these children so this is what makes
my voice stronger not my age although
it's quite hard to be an adult and but
being an adult does not stop me to
continue my campaign for children's
issues the 18th birthday is a milestone
for anyone why did you choose to spend
it here in Lebanon so well I have seen
many birthdays but this is a special one
and turning an adult it's a it's a it's
a big step in your life when you say I'm
not a child anymore I'm an adult but I
think spending it in Lebanon it has a
great importance in my life because I
always want every child to get quality
education and right now I was thinking
what's the best place that I can go to
and who are suffering the most and when
it comes to that the Syrian children
they're suffering the most
being refugees for more than four years
and deprived of education do not get in
any facility it's quite hard and the
worst thing is that world leaders and
international community is not paying
attention and that's what dragged me to
come here and celebrate my but they're
here to say to the world leaders that
you need to focus on it and you need to
invest here otherwise it would be a
generation lost to you when they're not
listening as much as they should to the
world's biggest most powerful aid
agencies well I'm hopeful that they will
listen to me because wherever I go I
tell one leader that you are not
listening to this one girl this is the
voice of millions of children so some
have some have not and it depends it's
all about politics and the leaders on in
and their own interest so but if you
continue it then ultimately they have to
do they have to do something in the file
first time they would ignore a second
time they would acknowledge but
ultimately our time will come that they
have to say yes two years ago on your
16th birthday you stood at the United
Nations and called on world leaders to
take action
urgent action you said to ensure every
child goes to school it's 2 years since
then - well at least since my 16
birthday I have noticed that now I'm
seeing what leaders taking more interest
in education there might not have been
much done on the ground but if you see
there is there was education summit in
Oslo and now in the sustainable
development goals people are talking
about 12 years of education it was in
the beginning they were only talking
about 6 years of education for children
and then 9 and now we have we have
campaigned and we have raised the voice
of children and said that note this is
primary education which nobody would
want for their own children so while you
are making it for the rest of the
world's children so we are saying that
secondary education is very important
for every child and it should be made
free for every child in the sustainable
development goals so I'm hopeful that
this voice would be heard and I'm
hopeful that the voices of these
children would be hard and I know it's a
long journey if it would have been that
easy then it would have been done long
ago but it's not that easy that's why we
are struggling every day you're 80 you
have two more years at school in Britain
in Birmingham what are your thoughts
about your future what are your plans I
don't think when I'm hoping to go to a
good university and maybe study I'm
thinking of Oxford
and I want to study peepee I'm very
interested in that and hopeful that it
would have good outcome and because as I
want quality education for every other
child I want quality education for
myself and I believe that this is how I
can empower myself to fight against the
ideology of terrorism the ideology of
extremism and the ideology of of - of
picking up weapons so I'm hopeful that I
can fight that I draw ideology through
getting quality education and through
learning more so quite hopeful time and
ways any an 18 year old not one who has
such a huge weight on her shoulders the
one who wants to have fun well I still
do not feel like an adult right now and
I not much has changed like yesterday
was 17 today I'm 18 and I don't think
much much has changed but I do feel
responsibilities which I always have
felt and it's not that people are
putting pressure on me it's the pressure
I have put on on by myself and I don't
think I'm unstable to any person other
than this inner person in myself I have
promised myself that I'm going to help
people and if I don't then I believe
that I'm unstable to myself and to God
because I have promised it
